Situation1: They have argued repeatedly this week about finances.
Expectation2: Greet clients and make them feel comfortable
Situation2: A familiar customer strolls in while the receptionist is free to chat.
Story: I stood behind the salon chair, scissors in hand, my mind still replaying the argument I’d had with Mia this morning. We’d been at it all week—money, bills, who pays for what. As her boyfriend, I knew I should be the one to break the ice, to apologize, to fix things before the resentment grew. But just as I was about to text her, the bell above the door jingled. Mrs. Carter, one of my regulars, walked in, her smile expectant. The receptionist was free, but Mrs. Carter always liked when I greeted her personally. As her hairdresser, I was supposed to make her feel welcome, to set aside my own worries and be present for her. I felt the weight of both roles pressing down on me—Mia’s silence on my phone, Mrs. Carter’s hopeful eyes. I wanted to be the attentive boyfriend, the professional hairdresser, but right now, I didn’t know which part of me to answer first.
